if nei(mid) is true, set max=mid, else min=mid+1.

children.text: The function nei(mid) subtracts for each log the value (log + mid -1)/mid -1 from k. If after all logs, k is >=0, return true.
children.label: code_analysis

children.label: code_analysis
code_analysis

children.text:
Wait, in Java, parameters are passed by value, so the original k in the solve method is not modified. So the function 'nei' is using a copy of k, subtracts the sum, and returns whether the result is >=0. Therefore, in Fortran, the function can be written as:

function nei(mid, logsLength, k_initial) result(ok)
    integer, intent(in) :: mid, logsLength(:), k_initial
    integer :: k = k_initial
    integer :: log, i
    do i = 1, size(logsLength)
        log = logsLength(i)
        k = k - ( (log + mid -1)/mid -1 )
    end do
    ok = (k >=0)
end function

Wait, but in Fortran, arrays are 1-based by default, but in the Java code, the array is 0-based. So need to adjust indices. So the first part of the Fortran program will read n, k, then the array of n integers. Then perform the binary search. Second part (second Java program):

Then proceed with the binary search. Now, the binary search loop:

min_val = 1

max_val = 1000000000 + 1000

do while (min_val < max_val)

    mid = (min_val + max_val)/2

    if (nei(mid, logsLength, k)) then

        max_val = mid

    else

        min_val = mid +1

    end if

end do

The function 'nei' is a function that takes mid, logsLength, and k, and returns a logical (boolean) indicating whether the sum is <=k.

The function can be written as:

logical function nei(mid, logs, k_initial)

    integer, intent(in) :: mid, k_initial

    integer, dimension(:), intent(in) :: logs

    integer :: k, i, log_val, term

    k = k_initial

    do i = 1, size(logs)

        log_val = logs(i)

        term = (log_val + mid -1)/mid -1

        k = k - term

        if (k <0) then

            exit

        end if

    end do

    nei = (k >=0)

end function

Wait, but in the Java code, the loop continues for all logs, even if k becomes negative. But in the function, once k becomes negative, the rest of the terms can be skipped. So adding an early exit if k <0 can optimize it.

    cnt = 0

contains

    logical function nei(mid, logs, k_initial)

        integer, intent(in) :: mid, k_initial

        integer, dimension(:), intent(in) :: logs

        integer :: k, i, log_val, term

        k = k_initial

        do i = 1, size(logs)

            log_val = logs(i)

            term = (log_val + mid -1)/mid -1

            k = k - term

            if (k <0) then

                exit

            end if

        end do

        nei = (k >=0)

    end function

end program main

function nei(mid, logsLength, k_initial) result(ok)

logical function nei(mid, logs, k_initial)

    integer, intent(in) :: mid, k_initial

    integer, dimension(:), intent(in) :: logs

    integer :: k, i, log_val, term

    k = k_initial

    do i = 1, size(logs)

        log_val = logs(i)

        term = (log_val + mid -1)/mid -1

        k = k - term

        if (k <0) then

            exit

        end if

    end do

The code outline:

program main

    implicit none

    integer :: n, k, min_val, max_val, mid, i, j, cnt, tmp

    integer, allocatable :: logsLength(:)

    character(len=20) :: s, processed_s

    ! Read input for first part

    read *, n, k

    allocate(logsLength(n))

    read *, logsLength(1:n)

    ! Binary search

    min_val = 1

    max_val = 1000000000 + 1000

    do while (min_val < max_val)

        mid = (min_val + max_val)/2

        if (nei(mid, logsLength, k)) then

            max_val = mid

        else

            min_val = mid +1

        end if

    end do

    ! Now, min_val is the result of first program

    ! Convert to string

    write(s, '(i0)') min_val

    s = adjustl(s)  ! remove leading spaces

    ! Process the string for second part

    ! Replace "BC" with "D"

    ! Since the string is a number, this won't change anything, but proceed.

    ! Create processed_s

    integer :: len_s, new_len

    len_s = len_trim(s)

    character(len=20) :: new_s

    new_s = ''

    j = 1

    do i = 1, len_s

        if (i < len_s .and. s(i:i) == 'B' .and. s(i+1:i+1) == 'C') then

            new_s(j:j) = 'D'

            j = j +1

            i = i +1

        else

            new_s(j:j) = s(i:i)

            j = j +1

        end if

    end do

    processed_s = new_s(1:j-1)  ! since j is incremented after assignment

    ! Now process the processed_s to count A followed by D pairs

    cnt = 0

    tmp = 0

    do i = 1, len_trim(processed_s)

        select case (processed_s(i:i))

        case ('A')

            tmp = tmp +1

        case ('D')

            cnt = cnt + tmp

        case default

            tmp = 0

        end select

    end do

    ! Output the count

    print *, cnt

    deallocate(logsLength)

contains

    logical function nei(mid, logs, k_initial)

        integer, intent(in) :: mid, k_initial

        integer, dimension(:), intent(in) :: logs

        integer :: k, i, log_val, term

        k = k_initial

        do i = 1, size(logs)

            log_val = logs(i)

            term = (log_val + mid -1)/mid -1

            k = k - term

            if (k <0) then

                exit

            end if

        end do

        nei = (k >=0)

    end function

end program main
